name: Stefanie Knight
clarity_response: A tool that maps dependencies between spreadsheets and scripts, logs every change with a timestamp, and creates an audit trail so anyone can understand and continue a workflow after the original builder leaves.
strongest_line: When the person who built the workflow leaves, the workflow dies.
what_feels_off: The testimonials feel constructed — 'Operations Analyst, Regional Healthcare System' is vague enough to be anyone or no one. The grant committee quote especially reads like someone imagining what a researcher would say. Also 'Stop managing files. Start defending your results' is trying too hard to be punchy and ends up meaning nothing specific.
objections: I don't know what 'CleanSheet reads the files' actually means in practice. Does it parse VBA? Nested IFs ten levels deep? What about workbooks that pull from SharePoint or network drives? My mess isn't a clean zip file — it's a nightmare of linked paths and manual exports. I need to know it handles that before I trust it with anything real.
gut_reaction: The opening line hit me immediately because it is literally my situation — I'm the person who built the workflow and I know what happens if I'm out for a week. But after that first section I started second-guessing whether this actually works on real-world chaos or just tidy demo files.
unanswered_questions: What happens with external data connections and linked files that reference network paths? Does the dependency map work when files are pulling from SharePoint or live databases? What does 'sorts out dependencies' from a zip actually mean — does it fix broken paths or just document that they're broken? How does it handle workbooks with hundreds of tabs?
price_reaction: $29/month individual is reasonable enough that I'd try it. $149 for team is where I'd have to justify it to my manager, which means I'd need to prove individual value first. The 14-day trial with no credit card is the only reason I'd even consider starting now rather than bookmarking this for later.

name: Angela Ramos
clarity_response: A tool that maps your spreadsheets and scripts, tracks every change with a timestamp and reason, and gives you a documented audit trail so workflows don't die when the person who built them leaves.
strongest_line: When the person who built the workflow leaves, the workflow dies.
what_feels_off: The testimonials sound slightly polished and the 'one sprint' success story feels optimistic. Also 'Change Receipt' as a feature name is trying too hard to be clever.
objections: I need to know where my files go. Are they stored on their servers? What's the data security model for files that contain PII or confidential business data? Also, if I upload a zip and 'CleanSheet sorts out the dependencies' — what does that actually mean?
gut_reaction: This actually hit close to home — I've been the person who built the thing everyone depends on and I've also been the person who inherited something nobody can explain. The dependency map alone is something I would have killed for six months ago.
unanswered_questions: Where do my files live — on their servers or locally? What's the data retention and deletion policy? Does it handle VBA macros in Excel? What happens when the dependency map is wrong?
price_reaction: $29 a month I'd expense without a second thought if it does what it says. $149 for team is reasonable if I can get even two other people using it.

name: Sean Aguirre
clarity_response: A tool that maps your existing spreadsheets and scripts into a dependency diagram and logs every change going forward so anyone can pick up the workflow without needing the original person.
strongest_line: When the person who built the workflow leaves, the workflow dies.
what_feels_off: The social proof quotes sound polished to the point of being generic. The grant committee quote is specific and believable. The AI code one feels like filler.
objections: I need to know what happens to my actual files. Where do they go? Who can see them? I work with sensitive ops data and I cannot just upload a zip to some SaaS.
dealbreaker_reason: No mention of where the files are stored, no on-premise option mentioned, no explicit data residency or encryption detail.
gut_reaction: The hook got me — that first line is exactly the conversation I've had with my manager three times. But by section 6 I'm looking for the thing that tells me this is actually safe to use with real data, and it's not there.
unanswered_questions: Where are my files stored after upload? Is there an on-premise or self-hosted option? Does it handle legacy Excel files with VBA macros?
price_reaction: $29/month individual is fine if it does what it says. $149 for team is reasonable.

name: Lindsey Davila
clarity_response: A tool that maps your existing spreadsheets and scripts, tracks every change with a log, and creates a documented trail so anyone can understand and continue your workflows.
strongest_line: If the original project was built by three people in Python, R, and Excel over four years, you'll see the dependency chain laid out instead of reverse-engineering it from filenames.
what_feels_off: The headline 'Every change has a Receipt' feels like it was workshopped in a branding session. The sub-headline is better but still has a slightly polished AI-copy feel.
objections: I need to know what 'adds a tracking layer on top' actually means in practice — does it alter my files, does it live in the cloud, can I still open my workbooks in Excel without this tool?
gut_reaction: This is talking directly to my situation in a way that is uncomfortable but accurate. The dependency mapping alone — I would have paid for that two years ago when I inherited this mess.
unanswered_questions: Where do my files actually live — their servers or mine? What happens to my data if I cancel? Can my colleagues who don't have accounts still open the underlying Excel files?
price_reaction: $29 individual is low enough that I could probably expense it without a conversation. $149 for team is where it gets complicated.

name: Angela Wright
clarity_response: A tool that maps your existing spreadsheets and scripts, tracks every change with a log, and creates an audit trail so the whole workflow doesn't collapse when one person leaves.
strongest_line: When the person who built the workflow leaves, the workflow dies.
what_feels_off: The testimonials feel too clean and too convenient — one for messy legacy systems, one for AI code trust, one for grant reporting. Real testimonials don't hit every use case this neatly.
objections: I need to know what happens to my data when I upload it. Is it sitting on their servers? Who can see it?
gut_reaction: This is actually describing my exact problem — I am the single point of failure and I know it. But I've seen tools promise this before and they always assume your project is cleaner than it actually is.
unanswered_questions: Where is my data stored and who has access to it? What does the dependency map actually look like? Does this work if my Excel files are genuinely broken?
price_reaction: $29 a month for one person is fine if it actually does what it says. The team tier at $149 feels like a jump I'd have to justify.

name: Edward Hayes
clarity_response: A tool that maps your existing spreadsheets and scripts, tracks every change with a log, and creates a paper trail so the workflow doesn't die when the person who built it leaves.
strongest_line: When the person who built the workflow leaves, the workflow dies.
what_feels_off: The testimonials read like they were written by the same person — too clean, too perfectly calibrated to the pitch.
objections: I need to know what happens to my files after I upload them. Where do they go? Who can see them?
gut_reaction: This is speaking directly to my situation — I am literally the person keeping the whole thing in my head and I know what happens if I get hit by a bus.
unanswered_questions: Where is my data stored? Is it processed on their servers or locally? What happens to uploaded files after analysis?
price_reaction: $29/month is low enough that I could probably expense it without a fight. $149 for a team is where it gets harder.

name: Jamie Rodriguez
clarity_response: A tool that maps file dependencies, logs every change with a reason, and creates an audit trail so that when the person who built the workflow leaves, someone else can actually follow what was done.
strongest_line: When the person who built the workflow leaves, the workflow dies.
what_feels_off: The social proof testimonials feel polished and vague. Also 'Start defending your results' sounds like startup copy.
objections: I need to know what 'CleanSheet reads the files' actually means in practice. Does it execute scripts? Does it connect to live data sources?
gut_reaction: This is the first tool I've seen that actually describes my exact problem. But I'm skeptical that the reality matches the pitch once I actually try to upload my file chain.
unanswered_questions: Does this work if files reference network paths or shared drives that aren't in the upload? What happens if a script has hardcoded paths?
price_reaction: $29/month individual is fine for a trial but if this actually works I'd need the Team tier at $149 and I'd have a hard time justifying that budget.

name: Courtney Montes
clarity_response: CleanSheet tracks and documents all changes across your spreadsheets, scripts, and data files so anyone on the team can follow what was done and why.
strongest_line: When the person who built the workflow leaves, the workflow dies.
what_feels_off: The testimonials feel a little too perfectly matched to specific pain points. And 'Stop managing files. Start defending your results' is trying too hard to be punchy.
objections: I need to know if this actually handles the kind of Frankenstein workbooks I'm dealing with — files referencing other files across shared drives, some dating back years.
gut_reaction: The headline stopped me because that is literally my job right now — I am the person holding this whole thing together and I think about leaving constantly.
unanswered_questions: What does 'we'll sort out the dependencies' actually mean when it fails? What file size limits exist? Who owns the data once it's uploaded?
price_reaction: Twenty-nine dollars a month personally is money I'd probably just eat if it works. But my team situation is the problem — $149 for 10 users is reasonable if I can get budget approval.

name: Johnathan Cook
clarity_response: A tool that tracks changes, maps file dependencies, and logs every decision in your spreadsheet and script-based workflows so the process survives when people leave.
strongest_line: When the person who built the workflow leaves, the workflow dies.
what_feels_off: The hero headline feels like it was written by someone who wanted to sound clever rather than just say the thing. The quotes are too polished.
objections: I want to know what happens when CleanSheet can't parse my files. That's doing a lot of heavy lifting with no explanation of what happens when it fails.
gut_reaction: This is basically describing my entire job situation right now, which either means they nailed the targeting or this is generic enough to feel relevant to everyone.
unanswered_questions: What does 'sorts out the dependencies' actually mean when a file is broken or circular? What's the actual upload size limit?
price_reaction: $29 individual is fine for a trial. $149 for ten users is where I'd need to make a case to my manager.

name: Andrew Livingston
clarity_response: CleanSheet tracks changes and maps dependencies across your spreadsheets and scripts so anyone can understand the workflow without relying on institutional memory.
strongest_line: When the person who built the workflow leaves, the workflow dies.
what_feels_off: The testimonials feel staged. The grant committee one especially reads like it was written by the marketing team. Also 'Stop managing files. Start defending your results' is trying too hard to be a rallying cry.
objections: I want to know what happens to my files when they're uploaded. What's the data handling policy?
gut_reaction: This actually describes my exact situation — I inherited a stack nobody fully understands and I'm the one patching it at 11pm.
unanswered_questions: Where do my files actually live after upload? What's the data retention and deletion policy? Does this handle legacy Excel files with VBA macros?
price_reaction: $29 individual is fine if it actually works. $149 for a team of 10 is reasonable but I'd never get budget approval without IT sign-off.

name: Ana Miller
clarity_response: It's a version control and dependency mapping tool for data workflows — spreadsheets, scripts, the whole mess — with an audit trail.
strongest_line: I kept getting AI-generated code from my team that I couldn't verify. I didn't trust it, but I also didn't have time to trace every function. Now I can at least see what each step is doing before I sign off.
what_feels_off: The hero headline is trying too hard to be clever. Also the 'when the person who built the workflow leaves' angle is fine but it's not MY problem right now.
objections: I don't know if this actually helps me understand what AI-generated code is doing or just logs that it changed. Logging that something changed is not the same as explaining what it does.
gut_reaction: This is closer to what I actually need than anything I've tried, but I'm not convinced it solves my specific problem — I need to understand code I didn't write, not just know that it changed.
unanswered_questions: Does it actually explain what functions do, or just map that they're connected? Can it handle AI-generated Python that's poorly commented?
price_reaction: $29/month is fine if it actually works. I'm not going to expense a team plan without proving it out first.

name: Pamela Fisher
clarity_response: It's a tracking and documentation layer that maps dependencies across your data files and scripts, and logs every change with a timestamp and reason so you can audit and hand off your work.
strongest_line: I kept getting AI-generated code from my team that I couldn't verify. I didn't trust it, but I also didn't have time to trace every function. Now I can at least see what each step is doing before I sign off.
what_feels_off: The hero headline is trying too hard to be clever. The 'Stop managing files. Start defending your results.' CTA is generic and could belong to fifty different products.
objections: I need to know how it actually handles AI-generated code specifically — does it trace the logic inside a function, or just log that the function was added?
gut_reaction: This is closer to what I actually need than most things I've seen — traceability, not just a pretty dashboard. But I'm not convinced it solves the AI validation problem specifically.
unanswered_questions: Does the change log capture reasoning for AI-generated additions, or just human edits? Can I export something that shows a supervisor not just what changed, but why each step is defensible?
price_reaction: $29 individual is low enough that I'd try it. The institutional tier at $2,500/year is reasonable for a grant-funded team.

name: Edward Richards
clarity_response: A documentation and audit trail layer that sits on top of your existing spreadsheets and scripts, logging every change and mapping dependencies so you can defend your work to anyone who asks.
strongest_line: I kept getting AI-generated code from my team that I couldn't verify. I didn't trust it, but I also didn't have time to trace every function. Now I can at least see what each step is doing before I sign off.
what_feels_off: The 'receipt' metaphor in the headline is trying too hard. The hero sub-headline is about knowledge transfer and offboarding — that's not my problem.
objections: I need to know if this actually traces AI-generated function logic or just timestamps who edited what.
gut_reaction: The second testimonial grabbed me because it's describing my exact situation. But the rest of the page keeps drifting back to 'what happens when someone leaves' instead of staying on the validation problem.
unanswered_questions: Can it actually explain what a function does, or does it just log that the function changed? Does it work with AI-generated code specifically?
price_reaction: $29 individual is fine if the product does what that second testimonial implies. $149 for team is reasonable.

name: Angela Sampson
clarity_response: A tool that maps how your spreadsheets and scripts connect to each other and logs every change with a reason and timestamp.
strongest_line: I kept getting AI-generated code from my team that I couldn't verify. I didn't trust it, but I also didn't have time to trace every function. Now I can at least see what each step is doing before I sign off.
what_feels_off: The hero headline feels like it's trying too hard to be clever. Also 'Stop managing files. Start defending your results.' sounds good in a pitch deck but means almost nothing.
objections: I need to know whether the dependency mapping actually works on messy, real-world projects. The clean examples feel suspiciously tidy.
gut_reaction: That second testimonial is literally my life, and it stopped me cold. The rest of the page is solid enough but I'm still not sure it solves the hard part — trusting AI-generated outputs.
unanswered_questions: Does it actually help me validate whether the logic in a script is correct, or does it just show me the steps? What does 'reads the files' mean for Python?
price_reaction: $29 feels reasonable to try. $149 for team is fine but I'm not a team lead so that's irrelevant.

name: Henry Harris
clarity_response: A tool that maps, logs, and tracks changes across spreadsheets and scripts so you can see what's connected and who changed what.
strongest_line: I kept getting AI-generated code from my team that I couldn't verify. I didn't trust it, but I also didn't have time to trace every function. Now I can at least see what each step is doing before I sign off.
what_feels_off: The 'receipt' metaphor in the headline is trying too hard. The hero section also pivots immediately to offboarding risk, which feels like a different problem.
objections: This looks like it solves the handoff and documentation problem better than it solves my actual daily problem, which is trusting AI-generated outputs in real time.
gut_reaction: The second testimonial is almost exactly my situation and that stopped me from scrolling past. But the headline and subhead felt like they were pitching to my manager, not me.
unanswered_questions: How does it handle AI-generated code specifically — can I see diffs or just that something changed? What does 'reads dependencies across languages' actually look like?
price_reaction: $29/month is low enough I wouldn't think hard about it if the trial works. The team tier makes sense.

name: Connie Obrien
clarity_response: It's a version control and dependency mapping layer you put on top of your existing spreadsheets and scripts so you can trace what changed, why, and how everything connects.
strongest_line: I kept getting AI-generated code from my team that I couldn't verify. I didn't trust it, but I also didn't have time to trace every function. Now I can at least see what each step is doing before I sign off.
what_feels_off: The hero headline reads like accounting software. Also 'Stop managing files. Start defending your results.' means nothing in practice.
objections: I don't know how well this actually handles Python dependencies versus Excel. Those are very different beasts.
gut_reaction: The testimonial from the Data Analyst about AI-generated code they couldn't verify stopped me cold because that is literally my life right now.
unanswered_questions: Does it actually help me understand what the code is doing or just that it was run? How does it handle code that calls external APIs?
price_reaction: $29 individual is low enough that I'd try it without much deliberation if I could expense it.

name: Carol Richardson
clarity_response: CleanSheet tracks every change made to your spreadsheets, scripts, and analyses and shows you how all your files connect to each other.
strongest_line: I kept getting AI-generated code from my team that I couldn't verify. I didn't trust it, but I also didn't have time to trace every function. Now I can at least see what each step is doing before I sign off.
what_feels_off: The 'Receipt' metaphor is cute but doing work the product description has to undo. Also 'Stop managing files. Start defending your results.' was written by someone who's never had to actually defend results.
objections: I need to know what happens when the dependency map gets something wrong. Does it surface false connections?
gut_reaction: This is closer to what I actually need than I expected from a podcast ad. The audit trail and dependency map are real pain points.
unanswered_questions: How does it handle projects where the logic lives partly in code comments? Can I export something a non-technical reviewer would understand?
price_reaction: Twenty-nine dollars a month is fine if it works. The team tier at $149 feels like it jumps fast.

name: Philip Hughes
clarity_response: A tool that maps your spreadsheet and script project dependencies, logs every change with a reason, and creates an exportable audit trail so anyone can understand and verify the workflow.
strongest_line: I kept getting AI-generated code from my team that I couldn't verify. I didn't trust it, but I also didn't have time to trace every function. Now I can at least see what each step is doing before I sign off.
what_feels_off: The hero headline is too cute. Also 'Stop managing files. Start defending your results' sounds like it was written by someone who's never actually had to defend results.
objections: I need to know what 'reads the files' actually means under the hood. Does it execute my Python scripts? If it's actually running code, that's a significant security concern.
gut_reaction: This is closer to what I actually need than anything I've seen — the AI verification angle hit directly. But I don't fully trust this page yet.
unanswered_questions: Does it execute my code or just parse it? How does it handle Python environments and package dependencies?
price_reaction: $29/month individual is low enough that it's not a blocker. Team at $149 is reasonable if it works.

name: John Mcbride
clarity_response: A documentation and audit trail layer that sits on top of your existing spreadsheets and scripts, mapping dependencies and logging every change.
strongest_line: I kept getting AI-generated code from my team that I couldn't verify. I didn't trust it, but I also didn't have time to trace every function. Now I can at least see what each step is doing before I sign off.
what_feels_off: The 'Receipt' metaphor is trying too hard. The Section 2 list reads like a product spec sheet dressed up as a benefit.
objections: I need to know how it actually reads Python and R dependencies. Because 'reads the files' is doing a lot of heavy lifting.
gut_reaction: The second testimonial is basically my job description, which is either genuinely useful or suspiciously on-the-nose.
unanswered_questions: How does it actually parse cross-language dependencies? What happens when the AI suggestions are wrong — is there a rollback?
price_reaction: $29 individual is fine if it works. I'm not expensing the team tier without a proof of concept.

name: Madison Vazquez
clarity_response: A version-control and dependency-mapping layer you drop on top of your existing spreadsheets and scripts so you can trace what changed, why, and how everything connects.
strongest_line: I kept getting AI-generated code from my team that I couldn't verify. I didn't trust it, but I also didn't have time to trace every function. Now I can at least see what each step is doing before I sign off.
what_feels_off: The headline reads like someone was very proud of a metaphor. The CTA is generic motivational copy — feels like it was written by AI, ironically.
objections: I still don't know what 'sees what each step is doing' actually looks like in practice.
gut_reaction: This is closer to my actual problem than most tools I've looked at. But I'm not convinced it solves the hard part.
unanswered_questions: Does the dependency map show me inside functions, or just file-level connections? Can it flag when AI-generated code has suspicious logic?
price_reaction: $29/month is fine if it actually saves me a day per week. I'd trial the individual tier without much hesitation.

name: Christopher Rodriguez
clarity_response: A version control and dependency-mapping layer for spreadsheets, scripts, and data analysis projects.
strongest_line: Every edit, every formula change, every decision gets recorded with a timestamp and a reason.
what_feels_off: The copy talks about tracking changes but says nothing about whether the statistical or analytical methods themselves are captured. This is audit theater, not methodological transparency.
objections: I need to know whether the tool captures analytical decisions — choice of test, justification for transformations, handling of edge cases — not just file edits.
dealbreaker_reason: Positioned as audit tooling but never demonstrates it understands what auditing a statistical pipeline actually requires.
gut_reaction: This is a documentation tool for analysts who lose track of their spreadsheets. That's a real problem, but it's not my problem.
unanswered_questions: Does it capture why a model was specified a certain way? Does it log transformations with justifications?
price_reaction: $29/month is trivial. The objection is paying for something that doesn't solve the actual problem.

name: Carrie Wiley
clarity_response: A change-tracking and dependency-mapping tool for mixed-language data analysis projects.
strongest_line: Which files depend on which. Where the data flows. What's connected and what's orphaned.
what_feels_off: The social proof section is suspiciously clean. The copy conflates 'auditability' with 'having a log file.'
objections: When I audit an analysis, I need to see the decision logic inside the pipeline — not just that someone ran a script at 3pm on Thursday.
gut_reaction: I can see the use case for teams that don't use proper version control. But for anyone already running a disciplined pipeline, this looks redundant.
unanswered_questions: How does it handle analysis-level decisions, not just file edits? What format is the exported audit trail?
price_reaction: Individual tier is fine. Team tier at $149/month is reasonable. Institutional at $2,500/year might be attractive for nonprofits.

name: Tina Price
clarity_response: A tracking and documentation layer that maps dependencies between data files and logs changes to analysis projects.
strongest_line: Flagged for you to review, not auto-fixed.
what_feels_off: The objection handling section is inconsistent — says 'It doesn't make decisions' but elsewhere describes checking for issues and surfacing outliers. That is a set of automated decisions.
objections: I've seen too many tools that claim to show you 'how everything connects' and then produce a useless high-level graph. I need to know the resolution of this mapping.
gut_reaction: There's something real here — the dependency mapping for mixed-language projects is genuinely hard to do manually. But the copy oversells the rigor.
unanswered_questions: What is the granularity of the dependency map? Does it read inside workbook sheets or just file-level?
price_reaction: Pricing is not the issue. The issue is whether the product does what the copy implies.

name: Derrick Hooper
clarity_response: A dependency-tracking and change-logging tool for data analysis files across Excel, Python, R, and SQL.
strongest_line: If the original project was built by three people in Python, R, and Excel over four years, you'll see the dependency chain laid out instead of reverse-engineering it from filenames.
what_feels_off: The headline metaphor doesn't hold. A receipt records a transaction. That's not the same as a provenance record for an analytical decision.
objections: The copy describes where data flows between files. It does not describe whether it captures what happens to data inside those files.
dealbreaker_reason: No mention of parameter capture, assumption logging, or anything that would survive peer review scrutiny.
gut_reaction: The product might be useful for a data ops team managing pipeline handoffs. For methodological auditing, it's not equipped.
unanswered_questions: Does it capture analyst intent, not just file edits? Is there any integration with analysis environments like RStudio or Jupyter?
price_reaction: Price is not the objection. Would pay more for a tool that actually solved the problem.

name: Carla Villanueva
clarity_response: A project-level change log and dependency map for mixed-format data analysis work.
strongest_line: That knowledge lives in someone's head. When they leave, the project becomes guesswork.
what_feels_off: The copy is organized around institutional knowledge loss, not around methodological integrity. Those are adjacent problems, not the same problem.
objections: I'm not called in because people lost track of their files. I'm called in because nobody documented the analytical decisions. CleanSheet seems to solve the former and not the latter.
dealbreaker_reason: Does not address methodological documentation at any meaningful depth.
gut_reaction: This is a sensible product for data teams with poor documentation habits. It is not a product for methodologists who need defensible analytical provenance.
unanswered_questions: Is there any mechanism for capturing the reasoning behind an analytical decision? Can a user attach methodological justification to a logged change?
price_reaction: Pricing is appropriate for the described use case. The issue is the use case is not mine.

name: Shelly Fox
clarity_response: A tool that tracks changes to data analysis files and maps how those files depend on each other.
strongest_line: Flagged for you to review, not auto-fixed.
what_feels_off: Came here via Instagram, which is already a mismatch. The language is accessible to a fault — words like 'receipt' and 'health check' obscure what the tool actually does technically.
objections: The dependency mapping claim across Python, R, Excel, and SQL simultaneously is a significant technical claim. The copy doesn't substantiate it at all.
gut_reaction: There's a real tool buried in here somewhere but the marketing is aimed at the wrong audience.
unanswered_questions: What technical methods does it use to trace dependencies across languages? Is this static analysis or runtime tracing?
price_reaction: $29 individual is easy to justify for a trial. I'd want to see the technical docs before committing.

name: Lori Welch
clarity_response: A change-tracking and file-dependency tool designed to make data analysis projects auditable by the whole team.
strongest_line: Every edit, every formula change, every decision gets recorded with a timestamp and a reason.
what_feels_off: The phrase 'a reason' is doing a lot of work. Who provides the reason? The copy is ambiguous on this and that ambiguity is a problem.
objections: Show me assumptions, parameters, and provenance — the copy gestures at provenance via change logs but assumptions and parameters are never mentioned.
dealbreaker_reason: The copy promises a paper trail but describes a change log. Those are not equivalent.
gut_reaction: I've seen tools like this before. They solve the easy problem — who changed what — and leave the hard problem unsolved.
unanswered_questions: Is the 'reason' field mandatory or optional? What format does it take?
price_reaction: The institutional tier at $2,500/year is the only tier relevant to environments where this kind of auditing is actually required.

name: Jason Rodriguez
clarity_response: A dependency-mapping and change-logging tool for multi-file data analysis projects.
strongest_line: Our grant committee wanted to see how we got from raw survey data to the findings in our report. We exported the full trail and that was basically it. They stopped asking questions.
what_feels_off: That testimonial reveals the ceiling: a grant committee stopped asking questions. That's a low bar. A peer reviewer would not stop asking questions after seeing a change log.
objections: I need to know what's actually in the exported trail. If it's a timestamped list of file edits, that's not audit documentation for serious analytical work.
gut_reaction: Interesting product, genuinely underdeveloped positioning for a technical audience. The dependency mapping across languages is the most credible claim.
unanswered_questions: What does the exported audit trail actually contain? Has this been used in any actual peer review or IRB audit context?
price_reaction: Price is not the objection. Technical credibility is the objection.

name: Leah Cummings
clarity_response: A tool that maps file dependencies and logs changes across a data analysis project for team accountability.
strongest_line: When they leave, the project becomes guesswork. CleanSheet writes down the logic, the dependencies, and the reasoning — so the next person isn't starting from scratch.
what_feels_off: The copy says it writes down 'the logic, the dependencies, and the reasoning' but nowhere explains how reasoning gets captured. Logic and dependencies are computable. Reasoning is not.
objections: On cross-functional teams, the problem isn't that people don't log changes. The problem is that the reasoning for analytical choices is undocumented. Does this tool enforce that?
dealbreaker_reason: Claims to capture reasoning but doesn't explain how.
gut_reaction: The copy is doing the classic landing page thing where it implies capability without being specific enough to be falsifiable.
unanswered_questions: How specifically does reasoning get captured? Is there a structured template?
price_reaction: Would not pay at any tier until the fundamental capability question is answered.

name: Craig Hughes
clarity_response: A tracking and documentation tool that maps how data files relate to each other and logs changes to analysis projects over time.
strongest_line: Which files depend on which. Where the data flows. What's connected and what's orphaned.
what_feels_off: The CTA 'Stop managing files. Start defending your results.' makes a leap the product doesn't support. Managing files and defending results are not opposites.
objections: I'm often called in to audit analyses that were perfectly organized — the problem was that nobody documented the analytical decisions. This tool would not have helped.
gut_reaction: Useful product for a specific operational problem. Wrongly positioned as a methodological rigor tool.
unanswered_questions: Is there any feature roadmap toward capturing analytical decision rationale? Has the export format been accepted by any journal or IRB?
price_reaction: Individual tier is fine for exploration. I'd try the trial but wouldn't upgrade until the core capability question is resolved.

name: Amber Alvarez
clarity_response: A tool that maps and tracks changes in spreadsheets and scripts so teams can see how files connect and who changed what.
strongest_line: CleanSheet adds a tracking and documentation layer on top. Your files stay your files.
what_feels_off: This is written for operations teams and data analysts at companies, not solo thesis students. Nothing speaks to someone doing a dissertation alone.
objections: I work alone. There is no team to hand off to. The dependency mapping sounds useful but the framing is about institutional memory and handoffs, which is not my problem.
gut_reaction: I came here anxious about my spreadsheets and this page talked at me about operations analysts and grant committees.
unanswered_questions: Does this work for a solo researcher with one project? Is there onboarding help for someone who is not technical?
price_reaction: $29/month is real money when I am on a stipend. The free trial is the only thing that makes this worth considering.

name: Jason Aguilar
clarity_response: A version control and dependency mapping tool for spreadsheets, scripts, and data projects that logs every change with a timestamp.
strongest_line: When someone asks 'why did this number change?' you pull up the log instead of trying to remember.
what_feels_off: The copy assumes I have a messy multi-person project with years of accumulated files. I am building from scratch. The testimonials feel cherry-picked — no actual names.
objections: My project is not that complicated yet. I do not need dependency mapping across Python, R, and Excel for four years of work by three people.
gut_reaction: This is a tool for data teams at companies, dressed up with academic language.
unanswered_questions: What does onboarding actually look like? Does this tool still provide value for a simple project?
price_reaction: $29 is fine if it actually helps me, but I am on a stipend. Team and institutional tiers are meaningless to me.

name: Brandi Cruz
clarity_response: A tool that tracks changes to your data files and scripts and shows how everything in your project connects.
strongest_line: Our grant committee wanted to see how we got from raw survey data to the findings in our report. We exported the full trail and that was basically it.
what_feels_off: The copy keeps gesturing at problems I do not have right now — team handoffs, multi-person projects. The product sounds like it was designed for a data team.
objections: I cannot tell if this helps me understand my analysis or just tracks that I did it. Those are different things.
gut_reaction: If it actually helps me see what my files are doing and creates a paper trail I can show my advisor, I might try it.
unanswered_questions: Can this help me understand my own methodology? What does the health check actually catch for a qualitative researcher?
price_reaction: $29 is a stretch on a doctoral stipend. I would need the free trial to prove this is worth it.

name: Matthew Brown
clarity_response: A file-tracking and dependency mapping tool for data projects that logs every change.
strongest_line: Missing values, broken references, schema mismatches, suspicious outliers. Flagged for you to review, not auto-fixed.
what_feels_off: The copy is technically clear but emotionally cold. It does not acknowledge that the person reading it might be scared or overwhelmed.
objections: I am under deadline pressure and I do not have time to learn what this tool even does, let alone integrate it into my workflow.
dealbreaker_reason: Time. I am in thesis year sprint mode and cannot afford the overhead of onboarding a new tool.
gut_reaction: This is a documentation and audit tool sold as a research tool. I would come back to this post-dissertation.
unanswered_questions: How long does it take to get value from uploading a project? Is there support for interpreting the dependency map?
price_reaction: $29/month means $348/year minimum. That is not a casual purchase on a research stipend.

name: Melissa Savage
clarity_response: A tool that maps your data project's file dependencies and logs every change so you can explain your methodology and hand it off.
strongest_line: Our grant committee wanted to see how we got from raw survey data to the findings in our report. We exported the full trail and that was basically it. They stopped asking questions.
what_feels_off: The testimonials have no real names. The hero headline is trying too hard to be memorable. The copy has that AI-assisted smoothness.
objections: I work mostly in qualitative analysis with some SPSS thrown in. The tool lists Excel, Python, R, MATLAB, SQL — no SPSS, no NVivo.
gut_reaction: The grant documentation angle genuinely appeals to me. But I am not confident this tool was built for someone like me.
unanswered_questions: What qualitative tools does this support beyond Excel? Can I document decisions made before I uploaded?
price_reaction: $29 is manageable if it saves me the three days I lose every semester reconstructing what I did and why.

name: Chelsea King
clarity_response: A version-tracking and documentation layer for data projects that shows file dependencies and logs every change with context.
strongest_line: Every edit, every formula change, every decision gets recorded with a timestamp and a reason.
what_feels_off: The product solves a legitimate problem but the copy does not acknowledge my anxiety. The emotional register is confident professional, not anxious beginner.
objections: I do not know what 'dependency mapping' will look like for my project. What if I upload my files and the map shows me something I cannot interpret?
gut_reaction: I am interested but not convinced. The page doesn't answer whether it is for me.
unanswered_questions: Is there support for interpreting the dependency map? Is there a tutorial for first-time users?
price_reaction: $29/month is not trivial when I am a doctoral TA. The no-credit-card trial is the only reason I'd try it.

name: Mr. David Hernandez
clarity_response: A project audit and change-logging tool for data files and scripts.
strongest_line: Missing values, broken references, schema mismatches, suspicious outliers. Flagged for you to review, not auto-fixed.
what_feels_off: This is clearly a tool for data professionals. No acknowledgment that a single researcher working alone might need this.
objections: I do not have a team. The entire value proposition is about institutional memory and handoffs, which does not apply to me.
dealbreaker_reason: The product appears designed for teams managing inherited, multi-person projects. My use case is not addressed.
gut_reaction: This feels like a legitimate product for a corporate data team that has been stretched to cover academic use with a single testimonial.
unanswered_questions: Does this work for solo researchers? What is the minimum viable project size?
price_reaction: $29/month on a grad student stipend is too much for a tool I am not sure applies to me.

name: Megan Smith
clarity_response: A tool that tracks changes to your data files and maps out how your project files depend on each other.
strongest_line: Every edit you make gets recorded: what changed, who changed it, when, and what it replaced.
what_feels_off: The copy is competent but generic. 'Stop managing files. Start defending your results' sounds like something a startup brainstormed in an afternoon.
objections: Uploading my zip and getting a dependency map might surface chaos I am not ready to deal with and cannot fix quickly. This could make things worse before they get better.
gut_reaction: The health check feature is appealing and scary in equal measure. This tool might be more useful after I defend than before.
unanswered_questions: What happens after the health check flags problems? Is there guidance? How long to go from upload to useful insight?
price_reaction: $29/month is a real commitment. The free trial is necessary.

name: Richard Robinson
clarity_response: A documentation and change-tracking layer for data projects that maps file dependencies and logs every edit.
strongest_line: Our grant committee wanted to see how we got from raw survey data to the findings in our report. We exported the full trail and that was basically it.
what_feels_off: The 'receipt' metaphor is trying to be clever and clever is not what I need when I am anxious about my research.
objections: I need to know whether this helps me produce better research or just document mediocre research more thoroughly.
gut_reaction: I am the kind of person this was built for — someone who knows their research question but gets lost in the files.
unanswered_questions: Does CleanSheet help me understand my data analysis, or only track and document it? Is there any educational component?
price_reaction: $29/month is manageable but I would need the trial to confirm value before paying.

name: Nicole Garcia
clarity_response: A tool that tracks and documents changes to your spreadsheets and scripts so you can explain your methodology without starting from scratch.
strongest_line: Our grant committee wanted to see how we got from raw survey data to the findings in our report. We exported the full trail and that was basically it. They stopped asking questions.
what_feels_off: The objection handling reads like a FAQ written before the product existed. Doesn't address my fear that I will use this tool and it will reveal that I don't know what I am doing.
objections: I need something that helps me actually understand my analysis, not just produce documentation that looks like I do.
gut_reaction: The core appeal is real — I am tired of performing competence in software I do not fully understand. But this page sells documentation, not comprehension.
unanswered_questions: Does using CleanSheet help me develop actual understanding of my methodology? What does the learning curve look like for someone with spreadsheet anxiety?
price_reaction: $29/month is too much to spend on something I am not sure helps me. The no-credit-card trial is the only hook.

name: Jacqueline Ramirez
clarity_response: CleanSheet tracks changes and dependencies across spreadsheets, scripts, and data files so teams can hand off workflows without losing institutional knowledge.
strongest_line: When the person who built the workflow leaves, the workflow dies.
what_feels_off: The testimonials feel polished and anonymous. The 'Receipt' metaphor doesn't land immediately.
objections: I need to know whether new staff can actually get up to speed on this without a consultant walking them through it.
gut_reaction: This is the first tool I've seen that directly addresses the 'key person dependency' problem we face every grant cycle.
unanswered_questions: How long does onboarding actually take for a non-technical staff member?
price_reaction: $29/month individual is low enough to trial without approval. $2,500/year institutional needs a business case.

name: Nathan Carroll
clarity_response: CleanSheet creates a logged, auditable trail of every change made to spreadsheets and scripts so teams can track decisions and hand off work without losing context.
strongest_line: When someone asks 'why did this number change?' you pull up the log instead of trying to remember.
what_feels_off: The objection handling section feels like it was written by someone who anticipated objections academically rather than heard them from real customers.
objections: I need to understand the failure modes. What happens when CleanSheet misreads a dependency?
gut_reaction: The accountability framing works for me. This feels like it was built for someone in my situation.
unanswered_questions: What's the data retention policy? Is the audit trail export tamper-evident?
price_reaction: Team tier at $149/month is reasonable but needs sign-off. Institutional at $2,500/year is competitive.

name: Alexandra Garcia
clarity_response: CleanSheet maps and logs changes to spreadsheets, scripts, and data files so that teams don't lose institutional knowledge when staff turn over.
strongest_line: You upload your existing files and CleanSheet adds a tracking and documentation layer on top. Your files stay your files.
what_feels_off: The product sounds useful but the copy is doing too much. The hero mentions Excel, Google Sheets, Python, R, MATLAB, SQL — that list signals 'technical tool'.
objections: I need to know whether this requires any technical setup or if a program coordinator with basic Excel skills can use it day one.
gut_reaction: The pain point is real and the framing around staff turnover is exactly what I deal with.
unanswered_questions: What does 'institutional onboarding' actually include? Is there a case study from a nonprofit with a small, non-technical team?
price_reaction: $29/month is fine to test. $2,500/year institutional is justifiable if it saves onboarding time.

name: Jordan Carter
clarity_response: CleanSheet tracks and documents every change made to a project's spreadsheets and scripts so teams can reconstruct decisions.
strongest_line: That knowledge lives in someone's head. When they leave, the project becomes guesswork.
what_feels_off: The page doesn't address change-management overhead at all. 'You're not migrating to a new system' is dismissive.
objections: I've been burned by 'just add a layer on top' tools before. The implementation always takes longer than the sales page implies.
dealbreaker_reason: No credible answer to change-management overhead.
gut_reaction: The core problem is real but this page is too optimistic about how easy it is to add documentation infrastructure.
unanswered_questions: How much time does setup actually take? Is there a migration specialist? What's the support SLA?
price_reaction: Price is not the issue. Change-management risk is.

name: Adam Jackson
clarity_response: CleanSheet creates a documented, auditable map of how data flows through spreadsheets and scripts.
strongest_line: CleanSheet writes down the logic, the dependencies, and the reasoning — so the next person isn't starting from scratch.
what_feels_off: The testimonials are the weakest part. 'Operations Analyst, Regional Healthcare System' is so vague it functions as a placeholder.
objections: I want to know what happens when the tool gets something wrong. What error rates look like in practice.
gut_reaction: The framing around accountability and handoff is solid. The trial offer lowers enough of the adoption risk to be worth exploring.
unanswered_questions: Does CleanSheet work on shared network drives or only cloud-based files?
price_reaction: Individual tier is cheap enough to test. Team tier at $149 is defensible if I can show time savings within 60 days.

name: Caitlin Hopkins
clarity_response: CleanSheet adds an audit trail and dependency map on top of existing spreadsheets and scripts so that reporting workflows survive staff turnover.
strongest_line: We exported the full trail and that was basically it. They stopped asking questions.
what_feels_off: The product positioning is slightly schizophrenic — it's pitching to individual analysts in the hero and then pivoting to institutional compliance by section six.
objections: I need a direct line from this tool to grant compliance or funder reporting requirements. The page doesn't name the frameworks or standards it supports.
gut_reaction: The grant committee testimonial is the strongest signal this was built for someone like me.
unanswered_questions: Does the exportable audit trail meet any named compliance standards? OMB Uniform Guidance, 2 CFR 200?
price_reaction: $2,500/year institutional is affordable if I can write it into overhead. $149/month team tier works.

name: Henry Bell
clarity_response: CleanSheet tracks every change made to a project's spreadsheets and scripts, maps how files depend on each other, and produces an audit trail.
strongest_line: If the original project was built by three people in Python, R, and Excel over four years, you'll see the dependency chain laid out instead of reverse-engineering it from filenames.
what_feels_off: The 'first five minutes' section oversells the onboarding speed. For a complex multi-year research program, I seriously doubt CleanSheet produces a useful dependency map in five minutes.
objections: I need to know whether junior staff can actually use this without a technical background.
gut_reaction: The accountability framing is what I look for in any new tool. The no-credit-card trial is the right move.
unanswered_questions: What happens if a file is too large or too complex for CleanSheet to parse accurately?
price_reaction: Institutional at $2,500/year is in budget territory. Team tier at $149/month is the more likely entry point for a pilot.

name: Jessica Flores
clarity_response: CleanSheet documents and tracks every change to a team's spreadsheets and scripts so that reporting workflows are auditable.
strongest_line: If it saves staff hours and survives turnover, I can justify the spend.
what_feels_off: The copy says 'you upload your existing files' repeatedly as if repetition creates trust. It doesn't address what happens when uploads reveal how disorganized we actually are.
objections: I need a quantified time-savings claim, not just 'pull up the log instead of trying to remember.'
dealbreaker_reason: No quantified ROI and no evidence this works for resource-constrained teams.
gut_reaction: The problem framing is accurate but the solution feels like it was designed for a team that has the bandwidth to implement it properly.
unanswered_questions: How long does it take to get meaningful output from a messy, multi-year project folder?
price_reaction: Price is not blocking me. Evidence of efficacy with under-resourced teams is what's missing.

name: Kelsey Hudson
clarity_response: CleanSheet creates a permanent, shareable record of how a project's files relate and how they've changed over time.
strongest_line: Our grant committee wanted to see how we got from raw survey data to the findings in our report. We exported the full trail and that was basically it.
what_feels_off: The three-step 'How It Works' is too generic — every SaaS product in this category says the same thing. No differentiating claim.
objections: Why is this better than version control tools that already exist? Git does dependency tracking and change history.
gut_reaction: I appreciate that the page is clear about what the tool does, but I'm not convinced it's better than tools I already use.
unanswered_questions: How does CleanSheet compare to Git plus a documentation layer? What does it add for non-technical users?
price_reaction: The pricing is reasonable in isolation but requires a comparison to existing tooling costs.

name: Steven Guerrero
clarity_response: CleanSheet tracks changes and maps dependencies across a team's data files and scripts, creating an audit trail that makes it possible to hand off projects.
strongest_line: When the person who built the workflow leaves, the workflow dies.
what_feels_off: The CTA 'Stop managing files. Start defending your results.' is ambiguous. Defending against whom?
objections: I've implemented tools before that promised to 'add a layer on top' without disruption, and every time there's a six-week transition period.
gut_reaction: The core problem statement is strong and I've lived it. The free trial with no credit card is the right offer for someone like me.
unanswered_questions: Is there a dedicated implementation contact at Team or Institutional tier? What's the realistic time from upload to useful output?
price_reaction: Individual at $29/month is low enough to justify personally. Institutional at $2,500/year is competitive but requires demonstrable ROI.

name: Kimberly Reed
clarity_response: A version control and audit trail layer for spreadsheets, scripts, and mixed-language data projects that tracks every change and maps file dependencies.
strongest_line: Every edit you make gets recorded: what changed, who changed it, when, and what it replaced.
what_feels_off: The 'Receipt' metaphor feels try-hard. 'CleanSheet' as a product name sounds like a budgeting app.
objections: No detail on how it handles version conflicts when multiple people edit simultaneously.
gut_reaction: This actually speaks to a real problem I've lived — the knowledge that walks out the door when a team member leaves.
unanswered_questions: How does it handle proprietary data formats beyond Excel and CSV? Can I self-host?
price_reaction: $29/month individual is reasonable to evaluate. $2,500/year institutional feels like a negotiation starting point.

name: John Quinn
clarity_response: A dependency mapping and change-logging tool that sits on top of existing spreadsheets, scripts, and data files without replacing them.
strongest_line: Every suggestion needs your sign-off before it touches anything. If you don't approve it, nothing changes.
what_feels_off: The social proof testimonials read as constructed. Real testimonials have rough edges. These don't.
objections: I want to see the dependency map UI before I upload anything real. Cross-language support sounds ambitious.
gut_reaction: The core value proposition — control without migration — is exactly what I need. The objection handling section is unusually direct.
unanswered_questions: What does 'reads the files and checks for broken references' mean technically? How does it handle encrypted files?
price_reaction: Individual tier is fine for a trial. Would need more specifics on admin controls to sell the Team tier.

name: Jennifer Chan
clarity_response: A documentation and audit trail layer for data workflows that maps file dependencies and logs every change made.
strongest_line: That knowledge lives in someone's head. When they leave, the project becomes guesswork.
what_feels_off: The copy keeps selling the problem rather than convincing me the solution works. After three read-throughs I still don't know what the interface looks like.
objections: No screenshots, no demo, no concrete example of what a 'map of your project' actually looks like.
gut_reaction: The positioning is coherent and the problem framing is accurate, but I'm a methods-first person. I don't see anything about whether it understands what my code is actually doing.
unanswered_questions: Does it understand the semantics of changes? How does it handle iterative analysis?
price_reaction: Pricing is reasonable. Not the barrier. Trust is the barrier.

name: Carrie Hale MD
clarity_response: A tool that creates a permanent, reviewable audit trail for data files and scripts, mapping how everything connects and logging every change.
strongest_line: Our grant committee wanted to see how we got from raw survey data to the findings in our report. We exported the full trail and that was basically it.
what_feels_off: The Instagram referral path makes no sense for this product. That mismatch makes me suspicious about who this is actually targeted at.
objections: 'We'll sort out the dependencies' is alarming, not reassuring. Also no mention of HIPAA or data handling standards.
gut_reaction: The core transparency promise is right for me. But the casualness around how files are handled reads as consumer-grade, not clinical-grade.
unanswered_questions: Is there HIPAA compliance? What are the data residency options? Is my data leaving my environment?
price_reaction: $29 individual is fine. Institutional at $2,500 is too vague for healthcare contexts.

name: William Brewer
clarity_response: A version control and dependency tracking system for mixed-language data projects.
strongest_line: Every edit, every formula change, every decision gets recorded with a timestamp and a reason.
what_feels_off: Calling it a 'receipt' is marketing language masquerading as a technical concept. The copy assumes I don't know git exists. That assumption is condescending.
objections: No explanation of how it integrates with existing version control. Does this replace git, duplicate it, or sit alongside it?
gut_reaction: The product might be useful for teams with lower technical sophistication. The copy is written for people who aren't already using proper version control.
unanswered_questions: How does this interact with git repos? Can I point it at a GitHub project? What's the diff view like?
price_reaction: $29 is fine to experiment with. The podcast ad sourcing suggests broad targeting.

name: Stephanie Zuniga
clarity_response: A change-tracking and dependency-mapping overlay for existing data files and scripts that produces an audit trail without replacing current tools.
strongest_line: You're not migrating to a new system. You upload your existing files and CleanSheet adds a tracking and documentation layer on top. Your files stay your files.
what_feels_off: The copy front-loads the 'person leaves' problem hard. By section 5 it's been restated three different ways and feels like padding.
objections: Team tier says 'shared workspace and admin controls' but gives no detail.
gut_reaction: The 'your files stay your files' line is the most important thing on this page for me. I don't want tool lock-in. The no-auto-fix policy is the right call.
unanswered_questions: What does the change log look like for a formula change in Excel? How granular is the dependency map for large projects?
price_reaction: $149/month team tier needs to justify itself against individual licenses.

name: Susan Greene
clarity_response: A project documentation and audit logging tool that maps file dependencies and tracks every change in a mixed spreadsheet-and-script workflow.
strongest_line: Flagged for you to review, not auto-fixed.
what_feels_off: The copy is polished in a way that feels rehearsed. Every sentence lands cleanly, which paradoxically feels less trustworthy. No acknowledged limitations.
objections: No mention of how logging works offline. Lab environments often have restricted connectivity. No file size limits mentioned.
gut_reaction: The 'flagged for you to review, not auto-fixed' line is the most honest thing on the page and it's buried. Lead with that.
unanswered_questions: Is there an on-premise or offline option? What are the file size limits?
price_reaction: Reasonable across all tiers. Price isn't the obstacle — trust and fit are.

name: Mr. Terry Williams
clarity_response: A change-logging and dependency-visualization tool that creates a reviewable trail for spreadsheet and script-based data workflows.
strongest_line: When someone asks 'why did this number change?' you pull up the log instead of trying to remember.
what_feels_off: The second testimonial about AI-generated code feels inserted rather than organic. It's the weakest of the three.
objections: My concern is whether this changes how junior analysts think about documentation — does it create a false sense that logging equals understanding?
gut_reaction: The problem statement is accurate. The solution sounds plausible. I'd start with the free trial for one smaller project.
unanswered_questions: Is there a way to annotate why a decision was made at the time — not just that a change happened?
price_reaction: Team tier at $149 is competitive. Institutional tier would need procurement.

name: Denise Thomas
clarity_response: A workflow documentation tool that maps dependencies between data files and scripts and logs all changes with timestamps and authorship.
strongest_line: Every suggestion needs your sign-off before it touches anything. If you don't approve it, nothing changes.
what_feels_off: The product name 'CleanSheet' implies starting fresh, which is almost the opposite of what the product does. Also the copy never says what kind of 'suggestions' the tool makes.
objections: The page never addresses whether the tool understands methodology at all, or just mechanics. Logging that a filter changed is different from flagging that the filter change affected statistical validity.
gut_reaction: The copy treats the problem as purely logistical. My problem is partly methodological. I need tools that understand the difference between cosmetic and consequential changes.
unanswered_questions: Does the health check flag methodological issues or only formatting issues? What 'suggestions' does it make?
price_reaction: Price is not the issue. Understanding of scope is the issue.

name: Adam Taylor
clarity_response: A documentation and audit trail system for existing data projects that tracks file dependencies and logs every change without replacing current tools.
strongest_line: If the original project was built by three people in Python, R, and Excel over four years, you'll see the dependency chain laid out instead of reverse-engineering it from filenames.
what_feels_off: The copy oversimplifies onboarding implied by 'drop in a zip and we'll sort the dependencies.' Anyone who has inherited a four-year project knows there's no clean automated parsing.
objections: I want to know what 'sorts out the dependencies' actually means when the project is genuinely tangled.
gut_reaction: This is the most honest-feeling product page I've seen for this type of tool. The emphasis on logging over auto-fixing and control over convenience is the right signal for my trust profile.
unanswered_questions: What does the dependency map look like when there are circular references? How does it handle incomplete parsing?
price_reaction: $29 individual is genuinely low for what's being described. Either the product is simpler than implied or it's underpriced. I'd try it at that price.
